description: From Portuguese ama (“female nurse”), from Medieval Latin amma (“wet nurse, amma”), perhaps an alteration of Latin mamma, of imitative origin, or from Ancient Greek.

entries.meaning: (India) a woman employed to look after children; (formerly) a wet nurse.
(Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Indonesia) a female domestic helper.
examples: Then one day he disappeared and when Luke called apprehensively at his apartment the old amah told him that ‘Whisky Papa runrun London fastee.’
